awd_titl_txt: IIBR RoL: Applying innovative structural tools to highlight RNA's structural dynamics as RNA-protein complexes self-assemble
awd_abstract_narration:
Life functions are supported by the interaction of large biological molecules, including  proteins and RNA.  Although the shapes or structures of some of these complexes have been visualized, very little is known about their dynamics of assembly.  How do these differing components interact to create complexes whose function exceeds that of either alone? This is a challenging problem because of the intertwined motions of the components. Through this project, new tools will be applied to highlight the motions of just one macromolecular species during the assembly of a complex.  Although both proteins and RNA are present, only the RNA is visible.  Students will design, build and apply the new technology to study the self-assembly of a small plant virus, an intricate structure consisting of a protein shell surrounding a nucleic acid core. These studies will allow us to more clearly define the rules that govern the joining of nucleic acids and proteins into biological complexes. 


Many important biological assembles are comprised of distinct macromolecular components, such as proteins in conjunction with the nucleic acids. Despite their importance, less than 2% of the static structures in the protein data bank reflect RNA-protein complexes. Even less is known about the dynamic interactions between RNA and protein components. Although much effort has been expended in watching one type macromolecule self-assemble, e.g. protein folding,  it is much more difficult to interpret dynamic structural information for multicomponent machines because multiple species are present.  The inability to separate the signal from the distinct components precludes a simple interpretation.  This project will exploit and innovate existing experimental infrastructure to create tools that highlight the signal of only one species on the background of the other, vastly simplifying measurements of complexes' dynamics.  Mixers that rapidly combine the protein and RNA precursors will be constructed and will allow experimenters to track the changing structures of only the RNA component during complex assembly.  A small plant virus will serve as a model system for these studies. The development and application of two complementary techniques (small angle x-ray scattering and single molecule fluorescence) will offer a unique perspective on this self-assembly problem. Once established, these methods can be applied other RNA-protein complexes, gathering data to elucidate the rules governing their assembly.  Project results, sorted by topic, will be posted at: https://pollack.research.engineering.cornell.edu/all_publications/. This project is jointly funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure program for Infrastructure Innovation for Biological Research, the Molecular Biophysics and Genetic Mechanism Clusters in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, and the Rules of Life initiative in the Emerging Frontiers office of the Biology Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The main goal of this project was to develop and apply new experimental tools to watch biologically important molecular complexes assemble from their parts. The main targets of the project were models of viruses, consisting of a central, information containing genome (made of RNA), packaged into a well-defined structure by a protein cage (capsid).  We proposed to develop new tools to mix the individual protein and RNA components together, and to watch them react and self-assemble into virus like particles.

 

A number of new tools were developed with support from this project. First, we needed to find a way to efficiently mix the protein and RNA precursors together, then to follow their reaction using x-ray scattering to measure the size, shape and combinations of the reacting molecules. We demonstrated the use of a new type of efficient fluid mixers and followed the reaction of proteins with RNA using solution x-ray scattering. Then, to get detailed information about the structure of only the nucleic acid genome, we optimized the method of contrast variation small angle x-ray scattering (CV-SAXS) for these types of experiments. X-rays measure the size and shape of biomolecules and their complexes; however, data can be hard to interpret when two different types of molecules are joined together. It can be difficult to understand the connection between each type of molecule and the features in the measurement.  This is very especially challenging for large assemblies such as viruses or virus-like particles, where a many copies of a protein assemble into a shell that confines the information containing genome. Using CV-SAXS we can identify experimental conditions where all of the proteins are rendered transparent, allowing us to measure the structure of just the genome. The long term goal was to watch such an assembly form in real time under two conditions: the first, where both protein and genome are visible, and second, where only the genome is visible (though the proteins are present). This approach would provide a new viewpoint on the assembly of large complexes like viruses. 

 

The arrival of the pandemic disrupted work on the project due to lab closures, however, as a result of our experience with RNA in viral genomes, we were able to shift our focus. Here, we selected to study a small, but important piece of the SARS-CoV-2 genome. This small element of genetic material controls the ratio of some of the viral proteins that are encoded by the genome. This ratio must be precisely maintained for the virus to successfully replicate. If this switch could be disrupted, it would be possible to reduce or possibly halt viral replication.  We were able to show that the structure of this so-called frameshifting pseudoknot looks very much like the comparable piece from the earlier SARS-CoV-1 outbreak, thus its structure appears to be quite important to viruses of this type. Further work combined our x-ray scattering measurements with atomically detailed simulations to determine a higher-resolution structure of this part of the genome. We measured the structure of this switch and a variant that is locked in one position, to understand how structure of this RNA element is related to its job (function).

 

Broader impacts: The broader impacts of this work are in two categories. First, we authored a methods manuscript that provides the details of protocols needed to perform CV-SAXS, making this challenging technique more accessible to others. Second, we participated in a number of outreach activities, both in person and on zoom during the pandemic, with the goal of teaching middle school aged students about molecular biology. My group developed hands-on activities demonstrating how molecules fold up (self-assemble) into biologically active structures, and other activities that illustrate how nucleic acid genomes code for proteins. Our goal was to inspire the curiosity of students and to encourage them to learn about science.

Modified by: Lois Pollack
